events.target_title: Disabling IPv6 has no effect

note.body:
Related: https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/issues/252

The `Disabled` radio button corresponds to [NM_SETTING_IP6_CONFIG_METHOD_IGNORE](https://developer.gnome.org/libnm/stable/NMSettingIP6Config.html#NM-SETTING-IP6-CONFIG-METHOD-IGNORE:CAPS).

---

>  `ipv6.method=ignore` doesn't mean 'disabled', just that NM doesn't touch IPv6 and lets kernel do it. Since NM 1.20 you can set ipv6.method to 'disabled'; on previous versions disable ipv6 through sysctl.
 
Beniamino Galvani in [NetworkManager#252](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/issues/252#note_249250)

events.target_title: New search behavior using type-ahead search by default

note.body:
I will try to explain a use case which I believe is not addressed by the current solution.

In my current directory I have many directories whose names all begin with a YYYY-MM-DD timestamp. I want to select all the directories from, say, May 2010. In any other file browser, this is easy: I type "2010-05" and my selection jumps to the first matching directory. I then continue to use my keyboard to select as many of the remaining directories as I want (e.g. in Thunar, I do this by pressing Esc to exit type-ahead-find and then Shift+Down to extend the selection).

In Nautilus, if I try typing "2010-05" in this directory, I have two problems:

1. The results are randomly ordered (2010-05-16 then 2010-05-14, then 2010-05-27...)

2. More importantly, I have no way of **visually verifying** that I have selected *all* the directories I want. In this case, search has correctly found the 15 directories whose name begins with "2010-05", but I have to be confident that I have entered my search string accurately and that the search feature has accurately interpreted it. I have no such confidence because the search feature gives every impression of being a "fuzzy" search rather than a precision search. The semantics of the search are completely invisible - it seems to be doing a pattern match against any part of the string, when in this case I want to match only a prefix. To reiterate: it is very important that I can clearly see that my selection is complete and accurate, and this can only be achieved by showing me the context around my selection (i.e. the 2010-04 and 2010-06 directories).

events.target_title: Make the Dash visible when no window touching it

note.body:
Florian Müllner said there is no dock, and no intention to add one. Well, with respect, there is a dock/favorite launcher and it's currently hidden. Back in 2010, it was clearly just a favorites list due to each icon being labeled as such, but GNOME Shell designers have since gone to great lengths to make the favorites list in Overview look as much like a dock as possible, so it's not really users' fault if they mistakenly think it's a Dock! This issue goes to the core of the Shell design philosophy and there is much misunderstanding. The question these people are bringing up is whether the existing "Dock" should be visible initially. This seems like a good idea and would be more efficient (initially), except that it would divide the users' attention between Activities and the "Dock" and also lead users to think the default "Dock" should have minimization upon clicking on an icon functionality like a taskbar, which it will never have by current default because it breaks the Shell default workflow, which removed window controls except for close in order for users to manage windows per desktop as opposed to per icon on a "Dock". Would we want a visible favorites launcher only by default? Obviously not. The question is actually whether the current default paradigm is doing what GNOME users want after a very long testing period. 

When you install Dash-to-Dock, you are essentially running two desktop paradigms simultaneously -- windows per virtual desktop & managing windows with the Dock as in Mac or Windows. Whether the GNOME Shell design philosophy is the better of the two paradigms (or if they can be logically and elegantly synthesized) can be left to the future. A clear explanation of the default UX benefits would be immensely helpful PR here. Where is that explanation? Personally, I can proffer numerous examples where quickly minimizing a window has been essential to my daily work, or how an intelligent autohiding dock better fulfills the dual purposes of window management and keeping maximized app workspace preeminent, while virtual desktops are still quite functional for manually categorizing running apps. So why only virtual desktops for window & app management by default? What is the advantage? Since Cédric Bellegarde (whose apps I respect) exhorted the community to maintain the current GNOME Shell design, I think he would do a good job explaining the benefits over the Dock paradigm.  

Pragmatically, whether the majority of actual GNOME users ultimately prefer the Dock paradigm and consider that more efficient overall, there should be a process to quantify that information and incorporate the result democratically into the design of future Shell versions, or else betray the GNOME mission statement: 

"The GNOME foundation must not stifle the interest of outsiders. An ill-conceived foundation could discourage outsider participation directly, by establishing rules which limit the ability of potential contributors to make their mark, or indirectly, by engendering an alienating sense of elitism. The stained glass of the cathedral creates a colorful spectacle for those inside, but from the outside, the building is just a hulking grey edifice, intimidating and impenetrable.

This principle has real, concrete meaning for the foundation: All discussions must be publicly viewable, any person must have the opportunity to contribute to the decision-making process, and every GNOME contributor must have the direct ability to influence the decisions which are made. The foundation must be democratic and friendly to those responsible for making GNOME what it is."

This conversation is obviously allowed and public, but I think many users might regard the latter promise of democratic flexibility as lacking after a solid decade of testing & remarkably consistent and well documented criticism without any reform. 

The GNOME Shell official documentation states: 

"The GNOME Shell designers are committed to empirical testing and validation. A large number of existing studies have been reviewed as a part of the design process and plans have been made for user testing to support the shell design process."

Is this really true today?

Lastly, I don't use Dash-to-Dock. I use daily the default GNOME Shell UX, but not by preference. The Dash-to-Dock extension has many problems like Overview window previews being stretched with the bottoms cut off, and the completely non-functional touchscreen support (for example, Dash-to-Dock has never had a working 'Show Applications' button with touchscreen devices! yet a slightly modded and still broken version is shipped by Ubuntu!). Why is this important? Because Jan Neumann is absolutely right. The vast majority of GNOME Shell users are being given a critically buggy version of Shell out-of-the-box, for the most part without any knowledge of the distinction between defaults and extensions. But why should there be this divide in the first place, except that Shell isn't meeting the essential needs of the majority of its users? Developers cannot isolate themselves from the community and dismiss this reality. The GNOME Project can't dictate what distros do or what users ultimately want, but it does have a responsibility to meet the actual needs and preferences of its community at least halfway for the sake of quality control and to prevent unnecessary fracturing of the product. 

Everyone appreciates the incredible things this project's contributors have achieved. Community members are trying to be constructively critical about the few major issues remaining for the good of GNOME.

note.body:
Hi Jerome, Thank you for your prompt response and valuable input. > My bad, it's a limitation I must document: You must always scan up to the end of the feed, even if you only want one page. > > Libsane backends sometimes crash when a scan is cancelled in the middle of a feed and Libinsane's TWAIN and WIA2 implementations have simply not been tested for that. > > So you are right, not reaching `session.end_of_feed() == False` is probably what causes your crash. How could I remedy this? Keep on reading bytes after ``session.end_of_page == True`` is reached? > Here you're getting the safebet implementation 3 times. While it should usually work, I strongly advise you to get it only once in the whole lifetime of your application. Getting it and cleaning it many times has not been tested. I was testing if that could remedy the issue (if it clears buffers to be precise). I will do as you proposed. > Those 2 options are available on WIA2 scanners but won't be available with any other API (TWAIN or Sane). Setting `resolution` is enough: When using WIA2, `resolution` is an alias created by Libinsane that will actually set both `xres` and `yres`. In this example, resolution was set lower to run my test quicker. I tried setting ``resolution`` option alone, but images made were still at the default 300 resolution. Setting it manually (``xres`` and ``yres``) changed the resolution of output image. I don't have that scanner available at the moment to check again, but I can come back to you results/logs/test scans. Kind regards,
Bogdan

note.body:
Hi Jerome, I've modified function ``scan`` per your specifications and added few log lines (other functions in ``util.py`` are same). ```python # util.py def scan(source): logger = logging.getLogger('libinsanelog') logger.debug('START SESSION') session = source.scan_start() try: logger.debug('CHECK END_OF_FEED') if session.end_of_feed(): raise Exception('Scanner unavailable') logger.debug('GET PARAMS') scan_params = session.get_scan_parameters() r = 0 img_bytes = [] logger.debug('GET FIRST PAGE') while not session.end_of_page(): data = session.read_bytes(128 * 1024) data = data.get_data() img_bytes.append(data) r += len(data) print('r = {}'.format(r)) img_raw = b"".join(img_bytes) if scan_params.get_format() == Libinsane.ImgFormat.RAW_RGB_24: img = raw_to_img(scan_params, img_raw) else: raise Exception('Unknown image format') r = 0 logger.debug('GET REST OF FEED') while not session.end_of_feed(): scan_params = session.get_scan_parameters() while not session.end_of_page(): data = session.read_bytes(128 * 1024) data = data.get_data() r += len(data) print('r = {}'.format(r)) finally: logger.debug('END SESSION') session.cancel() return img ``` ``scan_loop.py`` now looks like this: ```python # scan_loop.py import os import util import logging import gi from gi.repository import GObject gi.require_version('Libinsane', '1.0') from gi.repository import Libinsane logger = logging.getLogger('libinsanelog') class LibinsaneLogger(GObject.GObject, Libinsane.Logger): levels = { Libinsane.LogLevel.DEBUG: logger.debug, Libinsane.LogLevel.INFO: logger.info, Libinsane.LogLevel.WARNING: logger.warning, Libinsane.LogLevel.ERROR: logger.error, } def do_log(self, lvl, msg): self.levels[lvl](msg) def setup_logger(log_lvl): # create formatter formatter = logging.Formatter('%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s') # create file handler fh = logging.FileHandler('libinsanelog.log') fh.setLevel(log_lvl) fh.setFormatter(formatter) # get logger global logger logger.setLevel(log_lvl) # add the handlers to the logger logger.addHandler(fh) if __name__ == '__main__': setup_logger(logging.DEBUG) lib_log = LibinsaneLogger() Libinsane.register_logger(lib_log) scn_opts = dict() scn_opts['resolution'] = 100 scn_opts['tl-x'] = 0 scn_opts['tl-y'] = 0 logger.debug('GETTING API') api = Libinsane.Api.new_safebet() for i in range(1,3): if not os.path.isdir('scans'): os.mkdir('scans') img_path = os.path.join('scans', 'Image '+str(i)+'.png') logger.debug('GETTING DEVICE') dev = api.get_device('wia2ll:{6BDD1FC6-810F-11D0-BEC7-08002BE2092F}\\0000') try: logger.debug('GETTING SOURCE') src = util.get_source(dev, 'flatbed') logger.debug('SETTING OPTIONS') util.load_scan_opts(src, scn_opts) logger.debug('SCANNING PAGE') img = util.scan(src) img.save(img_path, 'png') except Exception as exc: logging.getLogger('root').exception('Exception occured') finally: dev.close() api.cleanup() ``` But error still persists. r = 0

    img = util.scan(src)
  File "C:\msys64\home\Bogdan\scanner\src/util.py", line 51, in scan
    raise Exception('Scanner unavailable')
Exception: Scanner unavailable
Which indicates that first loop ``while not session_end_of_page:`` did in fact reach end of feed. When second session starts ``session.end_of_feed`` is ``True`` still. I went trough ``libinsanelog.log`` and extracted following lines. Upon first check ``session.end_of_feed`` in ``scan.py``, we have this log:

events.target_title: Make a GIMP lite version
Make a GIMP lite version

note.body:
This is the heart of the matter. The complexity. But I'm starting in the middle. 
I know of about 10 people that I introduced GIMP to. Average smart people often wrapped up in their work which involves occasional photo retouching or putting together some layers to construct simplistic images. Each of them had the same complaint; GIMPs learning curve is steeper that Photoshop. Simplified, you really have to 1, dedicate some serious time becoming familiar with it and 2, have to use it on a regular basis in order to stay up to speed.
My analogy of the 747 I feel is apt. For the mundane tasks that these and so many people want from an imaging editor, it's a daunting program that the 5 or 10 hours a month doing simple jobs crowd is unable to keep up with.

To get to the point. Heresy. GIMP stripped down. Offering just the basics: brushes, color palette, eye dropped, color picker, blur, clone, air brush, each with little or even no adjustments like force, hardness, dynamic options etc. And the program would have the features the full GIMP has in the way of exporting. Want that Png shrunk? Hand it to GIMP lite to make it a jpeg. Simple common tasks. Maybe not even have layers.

I thought ideally, it could be the full blown GIMP but with a dumbed down feature. Most of the exotic menus aren't there and no pitfalls where the program refuses to do something because you have some obscure setting turned on, often something you don't even know exists.

events.target_title: Gnome on Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS text copying triggers apparently useless file writes
gedit "highlights" the entire file in red when the extension is ".cob".
gedit "highlights" the entire file in red when the extension is ".cob".

note.body:
Why should any lines be red? It makes them illegible.

How do you disable "Cobol Syntax highlighting" (which is a misnomer, since the entire file is being highlighted).

What is unclear? Rather than highlighting Cobol syntax, gedit is "highlighting" the entire document in bright red. What is expected, ideally, is to have the obvious bug fixed.

More useful description? I've already described the problem precisely.

1) gedit --version displays 3.28.1, which "apt" reports is the latest version.
2) Linux Mint 19.3, as already stated
3) Open any file with the .cob or .cbl extension using gedit.
4) The entire file is highlighted in bright red.
5) Cobol syntax highlighting, or no highlighting.

Additional information. The problem described occurs with .cob and .cbl files having sequence numbers in columns 1-6, which has been the Cobol standard since its inception. "Cobol" files without sequence numbers display some lines normally, with some form of highlighting, and other lines in bright red, for no apparent reason.

Attached: temp1.cob - has sequence numbers. temp2.cob - same file without sequence numbers.

[temp1.cob](/uploads/587ea79416414aa5b0c290ffb6e0ca3c/temp1.cob)
[temp2.cob](/uploads/299178871a479d9e51d45a20c0f9e115/temp2.cob)

events.target_title: Cobol: gedit "highlights" the entire file in red when file extension is ".cob".

note.body:
The problem appears to be in the cobol.lang file (which is why it occurs with both gedit and xed). Although I am unfamiliar with the syntax of .lang files, I note that the comment at line 55 states, "everything must start at the 8th column, except the line comment...indicated by '*' in column 7". This, of course, is incorrect. In fixed-format Cobol, columns 1-6 are used for sequence numbers, column 7 is used to indicate a comment ('*' in column 7) or a continuation line ('-' in column 7). Columns 73-80 are used for program identification (or terse comments). In free-format Cobol, there are no sequence numbers, and the is no program identification column. Statements can start anywhere.
I have no idea how to correct the cobol.lang file, but I will study the link you provided, and see what I can come up with. If I do manage to fix it, how do I share the result?

note.body:
I bumped into the same issue:

But on 3 computers I got the issue on only 1.  
On the faulty one: Cannot launch gimp with the installer `gimp-2.10.14-setup-2.exe` but it's working well when installing with `gimp-2.10.14-setup-1.exe`.

I am having the same error as @joeyhub with `gimp-console-2.10.exe`
```
>"C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\bin\gimp-console-2.10.exe"
GEGL-Message: 01:00:13.598: Module 'C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gegl-0.4\ff-load.dll' load error: 'C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gegl-0.4\ff-load.dll': The specified module could not be found.
GEGL-Message: 01:00:13.615: Module 'C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gegl-0.4\ff-save.dll' load error: 'C:\Program Files\GIMP 2\lib\gegl-0.4\ff-save.dll': The specified module could not be found.
Exception code=0xc0000005 flags=0x0 at 0x000000000591CB50. Access violation - attempting to execute data at address 0x000000000591CB50
Exception code=0xc0000005 flags=0x0 at 0x000000000591CB50. Access violation - attempting to execute data at address 0x000000000591CB50
Exception code=0xc0000005 flags=0x0 at 0x0000000000401D4D. Access violation - attempting to read data at address 0x0000000000000020
Exception code=0xc0000005 flags=0x0 at 0x000000000591CB50
```

On two other computers no problem with `gimp-2.10.14-setup-2.exe`

| config | Computer1 (faulty) | computer 2 | computer 3 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | 
| OS | w10 insider 2004 | w10 insider 1909 | w10 insider 2004 |
| Anti virus | windows | windows | windows |
| gpu | nvidida RTX 2060 | nvidia  GTX 1060 | Intel Iris Plus Graphics 655 |
| gpu driver |  441.66 | 441.66 | 24.20.100.6345 |

On the faulty pc: When replacing the `libopenblas.dll` from the bin folder installed with `gimp-2.10.14-setup-1.exe` to the bin folder installed with `gimp-2.10.14-setup-2.exe`, Gimp is working again.  
It looks like the issue is really on `libopenblas.dll` but why it's happening? no idea.

events.target_title: DRM_FORMAT_XRGB2101010 dma buffer format is not handled causing mpv failure on Wayland with Iris Mesa's driver

note.body:
having the same issue but for `Unsupported buffer format 808665665` on a Raspberry Pi 4 under the V3D mesa driver. Don't know what DRM_FORMAT that corresponds to, it's from playing a yuv420p movie in VC-1 codec.

My setup:
*  mpv 0.30.0 on gnome-wayland session with Broadcom V3D mesa driver 
*  Ubuntu 20.04 `focal` (dev branch) with -proposed and oibaf's ppa for more up-to-date libs and
*  mesa git from oibaf, currently at 20.0.0-devel 
*  Custom kernel (rpi-5.4.y branch from raspberrypi/linux) with broadcom V3D enabled and brcm clock enabled to fix the V3D DRM load on boot

relevant GNOME component versions: 
```
$ mutter --version
mutter 3.34.2

$ gnome-shell --version
GNOME Shell 3.34.1
```
For all intents and purposes, even though I've hacked around to make it possible, the Pi 4 setup I'm running on is a normal desktop Ubuntu setup as gnome-wayland is running under OpenGL accelerated mutter with no workarounds (oibaf ppa is only for convenience, stock mesa works but has the same issue)

events.target_title: Update Gnome Shell extensions from the command line

note.body:
Couldn't `org.gnome.Shell.Extensions.CheckForUpdates` be used for this (defined [here](https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-shell/blame/ebf77748a8477eb712287273b4b92a8e9a189e22/data/dbus-interfaces/org.gnome.Shell.Extensions.xml#L214) and implemented [here](https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-shell/blame/ebf77748a8477eb712287273b4b92a8e9a189e22/js/ui/extensionDownloader.js#L154))?
```
dbus-send --session --print-reply --type=method_call --dest=org.gnome.Shell /org/gnome/Shell org.gnome.Shell.Extensions.CheckForUpdates
```
Unfortunately, this fails on my GNOME Shell 3.34.2 with the following error:
```
gnome-shell[4608]: JS ERROR: Exception in method call: CheckForUpdates: TypeError: Main.extensionManager.extensions is undefined
checkForUpdates/<@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/extensionDownloader.js:157:9
checkForUpdates@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/extensionDownloader.js:156:5
CheckForUpdates@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/shellDBus.js:320:9
_handleMethodCall@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/overrides/Gio.js:327:67
_wrapJSObject/<@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/overrides/Gio.js:404:16
 ```
Currently, I'm using [this script](https://gist.github.com/N-Coder/9ec0eb11c2f14013c112e1468c708b30) (which is heavily inspired by the implementation of the "chrome-gnome-shell" daemon) to automatically click all the green update buttons and then disable unused extensions again. Of course, this probably needs a shell restart afterwards, but I usually don't want to quit all my applications (which seems to be a new thing under wayland) just for that.

events.target_title: Please watch the CanGraphical property on logind Seat objects before spawning a graphical login on a seat

note.body:
I've been hitting this bug for many months now on Arch Linux. Took me a while to get around to debugging this. Meanwhile many Arch Linux users are perpetrating [the work-around to bake KMS drivers into initramfs](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Kernel_mode_setting#Early_KMS_start), but that's not a proper solution.

Logs: https://gist.github.com/intgr/a7eee474994e8a845405a7466ac2ebc2

Please fix, it's really disappointing to see design flaws that were known about 7 years ago bite users.

(Issue https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/10435 helped me in finding this)

events.target_title: Please watch the CanGraphical property on logind Seat objects before spawning a graphical login on a seat

note.body:
Thanks @mraudsepp, that's very helpful and solves my issue.

I created an Arch Linux bug report to integrate this patch: https://bugs.archlinux.org/task/64985

events.target_title: Build failure in DAAP plugin due to deprecated G_CONST_RETURN usage in libdmapsharing library

note.body:
The issue is due to recent glib versions ( glib 2.62 in Ubuntu 19.10 ) which have made G_CONST_RETURN a deprecated warning. With -Werror the compilation fails. Later versions of glib have a better warning message than just a "error: const" message. 

The deprecation issue is fixed in libdmapsharing recently.

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libdmapsharing/commit/3d79874066e1a1c1bba646135cf5fc5811b0eb55

A new release need to be pushed to fix the compiler error / warning.

Incorrect Histogram Arithmetic Mean Values

note.body:
How many people are aware of equation **mean_absolute = mean \ (2^bitsPerChannel - 1)**?

Why not provide two fields for the mean values of histograms, and let users decide which units they want to use?

E.g.:
One field for standard RGB units [0 to 255].
One field for RGB units stated as [0 to 1.0].

Here is an example: http://colorizer.org

Thank you for your consideration,

Daniel Guibord

events.target_title: Saving to PDF changes text's font and size

note.body:
I have an xcf file which I've been working on for a few years using older versions of GIMP. I opened it in version 2.10.14 today and tried making a few changes, but there are a lot of problems that I'm noticing, perhaps related to this.

1) The font sizes within the file seems to be corrupted somehow. That is, a text block which was 90 px in the past, when being clicked on, is shown as 21 px. The preview is still at 90 px. But the moment I click the dragbars to resize the text layer, it immediately shrinks to 21px and then I have to change the fonts manually again.

2) When exporting to PNG, everything is fine.

3) When exporting to PDF, these problems are happening

    * The font sizes are all small.
    * Hidden layers are not omitted.


I'm attaching the latest xcf file and the old and new pdf outputs.

(Unfortunately I don't have the backup of the old xcf file)

note.body:
I have an xcf file which I've been working on for a few years using older versions of GIMP. I opened it in version 2.10.14 today and tried making a few changes, but there are a lot of problems that I'm noticing, perhaps related to this.

1) The font sizes within the file seems to be corrupted somehow. That is, a text block which was 90 px in the past, when being clicked on, is shown as 21 px. The preview is still at 90 px. But the moment I click the dragbars to resize the text layer, it immediately shrinks to 21px and then I have to change the fonts manually again.

2) When exporting to PNG, everything is fine.

3) When exporting to PDF, these problems are happening

    * The font sizes are all small.
    * Hidden layers are not omitted.


I'm attaching the latest xcf file and the old and new pdf outputs.

(Unfortunately I don't have the backup of the old xcf file)

[english-v2.pdf](/uploads/16cdd6ba593bb44a5fbd5c18a706cab5/english-v2.pdf)

[english.pdf](/uploads/3aa6bd1d9682d57f35be7d30535de061/english.pdf)

[poster1-modified.xcf](/uploads/30f0520728b158be59f8353fbf5d9ed0/poster1-modified.xcf)

note.body:
Another way to reproduce is to try to open a libre office PPTX (or DOCX, etc...) document.
*  keep the pptx file extension and you get the "Archive type not supported" error message,
*  rename to zip (since header 2 bytes are "PK") and file roller opens gracefully.

note.body:
Open file-png.exe and if it says "The code execution cannot proceed because **libgimpui-2.O-O.dll** was not found."
It's a typo because they should be **zeroes** not **Os**. How could someone fail at programming something simple? To avoid typing in **Os** instead of **zeroes**, use the keypad! **It's on the right side of the keyboard!** But, nope! That someone was lazy! There needs to be a keyboard that has the **zero** key **to the left** of the **one** key instead of **to the right** of the **nine** key. It needs to be intented.

note.body:
I've installed flatpak and paperwork but for some reason it installed 1.2.4 using this command

`flatpak --user install https://builder.openpaper.work/paperwork_release.flatpakref `

for some reason and had to use 

`flatpak --user install https://builder.openpaper.work/paperwork_master.flatpakref`

to get 1.3.1.

I wasn't sure if I needed saned running, so I did it anyways and added the loop address to conf.
So far the scanner has worked perfectly using flatpak version.

I've also flagged the packages on arch for update, so we should see a testing version of it soon.

I'll try getting ironscanner working on my system since there's no package or aur build for it, I'll have to compile from source which might take some time on this old intel 2500k.

EDIT: I compiled ironscanner and ran it, sent report.
https://openpaper.work/en-us/scanner_db/report/419/

Tiff files generated by GIMP cannot be deleted or used by other programs.

note.body: I had the same issue with files generated with GIMP. As often is the case, this is a Windows problem, in this case it is Windows Explorer. All you have to do is to terminate Windows Explorer (simply stop the "Windows Explorer" task in the Task Manager after opening Task Manager with Ctrl/Alt/Del). Before doing this, you need to start another application where you can access all files in the folder tree of your drive. I used 7-Zip, but I guess other archive programs such as Winrar etc. will also work. If Explorer doesn´t run in parallel, all files can be deleted. At least it worked for me!

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.14 crashes

note.body:
I'm having the exact same problem.  Fresh install of Windows 10 Pro version 1909 installed Dec 24, 2019 OS Build 1836.418 on a HP Z800 12 core Zeon CPU 2.8 ghz with 32 GB ram.  Installed RawTherapee, it works. Installed Photomatix 5, it works.  Tried PaintXP, doesn't work at all, gives a long cryptic error message.  

Intalled GIMP 2.10.14, nothing.  Changed compatibility to Win 7, Win XP, Win 8, Win 95, nothing.  In the compatibility troubleshooter, there is a 'test compatibility' button.  When you click it, GIMP shows up in the task manager list for a second or two, but nothing happens.  If you click it repeatedly, several instances of GIMP will show up in the list, and each disappears in order in the same pattern as you clicked the button about a second or so later.  Complete mystery, No ideas.  Uninstalled and reinstalled, as admin, etc.  Nothing.  

Uninstalled, downloaded GIMP 2.8.22 and installed.  Seems to work.  But Windows 10 does not seem to like GIMP 2.10.  Anybody have any ideas? Thanks

events.target_title: document gnomerc on help.gnome.org
document gnomerc on help.gnome.org

note.body:
Hi Andre,

Thank you for taking interest in .gnomerc.

> Where exactly to find a file called .gnomerc on a system?

It lives in $HOME, when it is present.

> Why do you think it is a "critical file"?

The name itself implies the importance of the file, I think.  For bash,
what file is more important than .bashrc?  Lynx, screen, bochs, and xfig
all have their equivalent RC files ($HOME/.lynxrc etc.).

It is critical for the same reason as .bashrc is critical: it allows me to
configure the shell from a script, obviating a lot of manual puttering
about I would have to otherwise do on each login.

> Which exact GNOME version is this about?

I am running GNOME 3.30.2.

- James P.

events.target_title: document gnomerc on help.gnome.org

note.body:
> GNOME by default uses dconf/gsettings for its settings these days.

I believe many aspects of GNOME are still controlled by environment
variables.  For example, in the discussion around a gnome-terminal bug, we
have

: Please double check you don't have G_MESSAGES_DEBUG=... environment
variable set anywhere
(https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-terminal/issues/42)

Setting environment variables like that is perhaps one use for .gnomerc.

The critical application for me, which I use daily, is suggested in my bug
report: at session open time I have to open a terminal window (preferably
gnome-terminal, but xterm if I must) which runs a shell script
interactively and which leaves me finally with an open, useful terminal
running the Unix CLI shell.

I definately do accomplish this today in GNOME 3.30.2 (on Debian 10) using
.gnomerc, so I think your search perhaps fell short.  The code may be in X
or Wayland, but it is difficult to understand why it is named .gnomerc if
this is the case.

My (quite functional) .gnomerc looks like this (some of it, the rest is
unimportant)

: ~$ ls -ld .gnomerc

: -rw-r--r-- 1 powellj powellj 840 oct.  31 15:28 .gnomerc

: ~$ head .gnomerc

: #!/bin/bash

: export TEXINPUTS=$TEXINPUTS:/usr/share/texmf/tex/bbdb:.

: # gtk-redshift -l 45.52307:-122.681296 &

: # tracker-control -k

: # sleep is necessary before starting artbox cos the db is saved on a
thumb
: # drive which will only eventually automount after the xsession is
started.
: # sleep 5

: # xeyes &

: # sleep 5

: # xmessage "insert meow please"

: ~$


This excerpt indicates some of the utility of .gnomerc.  Before GNOME Shell
added 'Night Mode' there was gtk-redshift, which I have been using for
years to the same effect.  How am I supposed to accomplish workarounds to
GNOME Shell limitations without .gnomerc?

So, again I would definately like to see this function documented, and to
be pointed to that documentation.

Thanks for taking the time to look at this.  I won't argue it's beyond
beginner material.  In my opinion it belongs at help.gnome.org but as I
said there's no place to report a bug for that site that I can locate today.

I am also curious if you might suggest some other, more GNOME-like way of
accomplishing my goal of configuring my GNOME Shell environment (invoking
the full power of linux and not just some GNOME dconf settings)
automatically at login, and launching interactive shell scripts at login
automatically?

yours truly,
  James P.

events.target_title: document gnomerc on help.gnome.org

note.body:
These are the details of gnomerc on Debian 10.  Short story: it's part of
the gnome-session package, and cleanly invoked during init.

Details: several mentions of the file in the system (grep results follow):


/etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc:# If we are running the GNOME
session, source ~/.gnomerc
/etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc:    GNOMERC=$HOME/.gnomerc
/usr/share/doc/gnome-session/README.Debian:.gnomerc file the following:
/var/lib/dpkg/info/gnome-session-common.list:/etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc
/var/backups/dpkg.status.0: /etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc
0d6fbd1c962e79b114c8e9278c820232

More details: the dpkg.status.0 file lists gnomerc in gnome-session:

: Status: install ok installed

: Priority: optional

: Section: gnome

: Installed-Size: 1208

: Maintainer: Debian GNOME Maintainers
<pkg-gnome-maintainers@lists.alioth.debi$
: Architecture: all

: Source: gnome-session

: Version: 3.30.1-2

: Breaks: evince (<< 3.30)

: Conffiles:

:  /etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc
0d6fbd1c962e79b114c8e9278c820232
: Description: GNOME Session Manager - common files

:  The GNOME Session Manager is in charge of starting the core components

:  of the GNOME desktop, and applications that should be launched at

:  login time. It also features a way to save and restore currently

:  running applications.

:  .

:  This package contains the translations, data files and startup scripts

:  which are common to the GNOME and GNOME fallback sessions.


There's no indication of it being Debian-only...?

Many thanks.

- JP

events.target_title: document gnomerc on help.gnome.org

note.body:
I can also do my own homework with respect to "I am also curious if you
might suggest some other, more GNOME-like way of accomplishing my goal".  I
have already noticed this text from README.Debian:

: Applications at startup

: -----------------------

:

: Upon startup, gnome-session starts the following applications:

:  - Saved session: if you have saved a session, it is located in

:    ~/.config/gnome-session/saved-session/. You can enable automatic

:    session saving or manually save it in the "Startup Applications"

:    configuration applet.

:  - Autostart applications: applications shipping a .desktop file in

:    /usr/share/gnome/autostart or /etc/xdg/autostart. This includes the

:    keyring manager, the settings daemon, nautilus and the power

:    manager. They can be selectively disabled in the configuration

:    applet.

:  - Required components: they are listed in the

:    /usr/share/gnome-session/sessions/*.desktop file corresponding to the

:    current session (gnome or gnome-fallback).


So please don't bother about that, I can follow up on this.

- JP

Hi @aklapper and thanks for the reply.
I indeed wondered about the version difference, but note that 3.26 is the latest version I could find in https://help.gnome.org/admin/gdm/.

caribou isn't installed in my system.

Searching more within the repo, I can find:

```console
$ grep -R keyboard data/*
data/dconf/defaults/locks/00-upstream-settings-locks:/org/gnome/desktop/a11y/keyboard/enable
```

I'll assume that you're just delegating the responsibility to launch the keyboard to gnome, and it's up to him to decide which software to use.
I suppose that's where a desktop manager comes in handy, while I need to set manual rules for everything when using just a window manager.

Gnome doesn't say much in its documentation:
https://help.gnome.org/users/gnome-help/stable/keyboard-osk.html.en

Wondering why this is so well hidden.

events.target_title: Color profile for laptop screen is wrongly applied to one of my external monitors instead

note.body: I have two identical Acer monitors. The two edid files in the /sys filesystem have the same ASCII serial numbers in the display descriptor ASCII serial number field. The unique part of the serial number is found in the serial number field (bytes 12-15) in the header section. In gnome color settings, I only get one monitor listed. Does gnome color manager use the serial number in the edid header or only the ASCII serial number in the display descriptor? This may be why it is not detecting two displays.

events.target_title: Add -l/-c/-p command line args
Bad font rendering with 1.44

note.body:
I have a pretty bad case of this myself. The upper line is the old and the lower is the new rendering:

![Pango-DejaVu-spacing](/uploads/a5787cba54d60c801e83608cdc7a518a/Pango-DejaVu-spacing.png)

The test text is waffinityowowMoMWoWtTdTaTomTifioioidildlqlIoIqIdSizeffle

Not only is the text about 10% wider, the spacing between glyphs is very uneven, in some cases reaching 4 pixels - the width of a full space (there are no spaces in the text). It was at most 2 pixels in the old rendering, and much more consistent.

The font is DejaVu Sans Book, size 10. 
Here's my fontconfig:
```
 <match target="font">
  <edit mode="assign" name="rgba">
   <const>none</const>
  </edit>
 </match>
 <match target="font">
  <edit mode="assign" name="hinting">
   <bool>true</bool>
  </edit>
 </match>
 <match target="font">
  <edit mode="assign" name="hintstyle">
   <const>hintfull</const>
  </edit>
 </match>
 <match target="font">
  <edit mode="assign" name="antialias">
   <bool>true</bool>
  </edit>
 </match>
 <match target="font">
  <edit mode="assign" name="lcdfilter">
    <const>lcdnone</const>
  </edit>
 </match>
```
I'm also using [bytecode interpreter version 35 in FreeType](https://www.freetype.org/freetype2/docs/reference/ft2-properties.html#tt_interpreter_version_35)

Wrong color profile conversion of images with wavelet decompose layer groups
Add .avif (AV1 Image File Format) support

note.body:
GIMP uses plug-ins to support additional file formats. There is no need for new version, you just add the compiled plugin to .config/GIMP/2.10/plug-ins/ folder and support is there.
I started to create such plug-in as a hobby - to refresh my programming skills, I am inexperienced with GIMP API and with GEGL yet.
So far I am able to load 8bit and 10bit images.
My plug-in needs libaom and libavif installed first.

events.target_title: Retain Original Created Date and Modified Date when exporting as WEBP, JPG, and other formats

note.body:
I can be wrong, but for now GIMP does not write any data in EXIF/XMP fields for WEBP (despite you can checkmark both while writing) - so not only date is missing, but all manufacturer data, gps fields etc.
```
$ exiv2 -pt test.webp // empty - no output
$ exiv2 -pt test.jpeg | wc -l // file that is source for webp image
56
$ exiv2 -pt test.jpeg | head
Exif.Image.Make                              Ascii       8  samsung
Exif.Image.Model                             Ascii       9  SM-G955F
Exif.Image.Orientation                       Short       1  top, left
Exif.Image.XResolution                       Rational    1  72
Exif.Image.YResolution                       Rational    1  72
Exif.Image.ResolutionUnit                    Short       1  inch
Exif.Image.Software                          Ascii      13  GIMP 2.10.14
Exif.Image.DateTime                          Ascii      20  2020:01:03 11:37:15
Exif.Image.YCbCrPositioning                  Short       1  Centered
Exif.Image.ExifTag                           Long        1  214

```
